text: Family Member: I will thank you. Patient: I’m home boarding the dog. (chuckles) Family Member: Daddy, you want to come take care of (says name) Patient: Oh okay. In terms of Doctor: But if he doesn’t he can go. Family Member: Oh, oh, he can? Doctor: Yeah. It’s only those four days. Family Member: OOH! It’s the first of the week of the week that you get it. Doctor: Of the week you get it, I don’t want you on the plane Thursday through Sunday. Patient: Right. Doctor: But the rest of the time you’re free. So you can go on the twenty-sixth. text: Family Member: So it has pretty good results in Germany? Doctor: And so what they’ve done different than we do here is they report it on their experience. So they’re like we treated these six-hundred people, people with different stage, and different things, and they try to give some data about how the people live, what was their survival, and they showed you know tumor shrinking, and their response rate. And so overall that Gestalt, that’s a German word. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: That looks, looks really good, I think. And then they collaborate with this gentleman that I have experience with in Turkey, seeing the data presented. I mean you share but you know some of the data that shows incredible responses to these. So I think part of it depends on how active your cancer is for this study, for this, this for the PSMA. Patient: Okay. Okay. Family Member: And then if you see the result, you would know probably in two months if you saw the results? Doctor: Yes. Family Member: And then if you didn’t see results, would you go to a bone marrow? Patient: Right. Doctor: Well, we could do chemotherapy still. We could do a trial of chemotherapy. Uh you know the bone marrow transplant to me, you know, it’s a trial that I’m doing. You know it’s the only treatment I know of that cures cancer. So if you take people with bad leukemia and bad lymphoma you can cure them- Family Member: Um hum. Doctor: by giving them somebody else’s immune system. Family Member: Um hum.

text: Patient: Okay. Doctor: Um okay. Patient: Are they, did E_ --- Doctor: And, then, you know, I would say your brother who has prostate cancer he probably should get tested because it’s, you know, it’s possible he has the same gene mutation, um, inherited because it is a risk factor. So, from the standpoint of your family, that’s my advice – they get tested. For you personally, what does it mean? (pause) Patient: Mm, hmm. Doctor: We’ve also been doing clinical studies in a weird way with giving men testosterone Patient: Mm, hmm. Doctor: Who become resistant to hormones. Patient: Yeah, you talked about that. Doctor: And one of the things we’re observing is men who have BRCA2 mutation seem to respond really well to getting testosterone. We’re trying to figure out why. We just put in a big grant to kind of study this. So, so, we are about to, uh, have some trials where we’re – one of our trials is, if a guy has a mutation in this and he maybe responds to testosterone and he maybe responds to immune therapy, what if we give him both? Um. So, that’s a trial down the road that’s going to open up, um, probably in the next six months. We can talk more about that. Patient: If you get the grant? Doctor: No, we got that already. Patient: Oh.

text: Patient: Uh hum. Doctor: And if you do go back on that program, which it sounds like you’ve already done on your own. Patient: Yeah. text: Patient: Huh, I would say, sometimes it’s a five on my neck, especially when I turn it. Doctor: Okay. And so- Patient: Before, it was turning to the left and it was turning to the right because I wanted to start driving. But now, when I turn it to the left it seems like right there you can feel the bone. Doctor: So you’ve not been able to drive yet because you can’t twist your neck enough? Patient: Right. Family Member: And on your (voice) Patient: Or bend it backwards. The right side ain’t bothering me. It’s just that one that, well, the one that the screw came loose. Doctor: Okay. And, huh, any numbness or tingling? Patient: What? In my neck? Doctor: Your arms, your legs. Patient: No. And the only other thing that now and then is my shoulder blade from the day, from the first day that I was operated on. I was telling the nurse and everything while I was still in the hospital it felt like I had three shoulder blades at times. In fact, I told you that. Doctor: Is that getting worse? Or is it just present?

text: Patient: And so the likelihood of what you’re seeing reoccurring is is is it high, minimum? Doctor: I would say, I would say based on so far minimum. Patient: Um hmm. text: Healthcare Professional: How long ago, I haven’t checked with Doctor: No. How long ago was his previous one? Do we know? Healthcare Professional: It was in July, it was four point two. Doctor: July…So, it’s been Healthcare Professional: Yeah. Doctor: Two months almost. Okay. I’m going to plan for doing repeat scans. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Because, obviously, if today’s PSA keeps on going up, we need to look and see what’s going on. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Okay? Patient: Okay.

text: Patient: Everything is, and then you have some passages- Doctor: I mean, like the poor areas of the country, that was part of the tour, or you just look out the window and that’s what you see? Patient: Langa is a little town. Family Member: It’s a little town outside of Cape Town. Patient: Right. Family Member: Very poor. It’s like they forgot about that part. Patient: You ain’t lying. Family Member: Because we added Robben Island, and so they added that part so we could go see that. That’s the first history over there. Patient: Yeah. So we had a tour guide when we went there. text: Patient: Mhm. Doctor: But if it has dropped on its own, then I will rewrite your prescription and reauthorize your prescription for the Abiraterone. Patient: Mhm. Doctor: But, having said all that, I do anticipate that we’re going to be switching gears. Patient: Okay. Sound good to me. Doctor: Are there any other questions you have for me about the clinical trial or about the Xtandi itself? Patient: No. Um, none at this time. Doctor: Okay. So, what we’ll do is we’ll um we’ll be able to answer some questions over the phone when we call you as well in about a week. Patient: Mhm. Doctor: Talk to you about the clinical trials. If you read through this and you say thanks but no thanks, that’s perfectly fine. I’m still going to be your doc and I’m still going to be your oncologist. Um and you have every right you know to turn this down if it’s not right for you. Patient: Mhm. Doctor: But this a reasonable option that um if I was the patient, I would also consider. So I will leave that with you, put that underneath this one.

Doctor-Patient-Conversation-Analysis-pos.text: Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.
Doctor-Patient-Conversation-Analysis-pos.displayed_text: Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.
